aliansi influenced by Dutch alliantie, persekutuan

Malaysian: pangsapuri, rumah pangsa, rumah kondo (only for 'condominium')
Indonesian: apartemen influenced by Dutch appartement, rumah susun (rusun), kondominium

Malaysian: majlis, perhimpunan (from the root verb 'himpun' meaning 'to gather/assemble')

Indonesian: harta, aset, aktiva from Dutch activa
asosiasi from Dutch associatie, perhimpunan, perkumpulan
Athena influenced by Dutch Athene or from native Greek Athina

Malaysian: makcik (also used in bahasa Melayu Riau in Indonesia), emak saudara, ibu saudara

Indonesian: autobiografi - otobiografi is a substandard spelling
otomatis derived from Dutch pronunciation of automatisch
matras influenced by Dutch matras, tempat tidur, ranjang, kasur
papan iklan, papan reklame from Dutch reclame (advertisement)
pemberhentian bus, halte bus substandard, from Dutch bushalte
kampanye from Dutch campagne (which is a French loanword)

Malaysian:
kereta 
(means carriage in Indonesian, commonly used as a shorthand for kereta api, which means train. Malaysian followed English derivation of car which was a contraction of horseless carriage)

Indonesian: kasir from Dutch kassier, juru uang

Malaysian: cili, lada('pepper' in Indonesian), cabai (used in the northern states of Malaysia)

Indonesian:
China proper name appealed by the Chinese embassy, 
Cina still in common use but discouraged by the Chinese embassy due to possible racist connotations, 
Tiongkok archaic

Malaysian: panggung wayang bergambar (more popularly abbreviated as pawagam), panggung wayang

Indonesian: kecoak from the Chinese Min Nan ka chuah
perusahaan, firma, maskapai from Dutch maatschappij - almost exclusively used to refer to airline companies, i.e. maskapai penerbangan
undang-undang dasar influenced by Dutch grondwet (basic law), konstitusi from Dutch constitutie
negara, negeri in Malaysia, negeri only refers to a state within a federation
pengadilan, mahkamah only refers to the institution
lemari from older term almari, which also came from Portuguese armário
saat ini, kini, terkini, aktual from Dutch actueel
pabean refers to the administrative institution, bea dan cukai (bea-cukai) lit. tariff-and-tax, duty
surat keputusan, dekrit from Dutch decreet

demokratis from Dutch demokratisch 
note: "democratic republic" (in country names) translates as republik demokratik, such as in Republik Demokratik Kongo (Democratic Republic of the Congo)
direktur from Dutch (and French) directeur, (of a film) sutradara from Sanskrit (through Javanese)
diskon, rabat, potongan harga, korting from Dutch, less frequent
sopir from French chauffeur through Dutch, pengemudi formal
editor, penyunting, redaktur from French rédacteur through Dutch - refers to editors of mass media, esp. newspapers, magazines, etc.
Idulfitri - Idul Fitri substandard spelling, but common, Lebaran colloquial - from Javanese

Malaysian: lapan used as colloquial abbreviation in Indonesian
Indonesian: delapan used in Malaysia before the spelling reform
listrik, kelistrikan, setrum from Dutch Stroom
darurat from Arabic - also used in Malaysia to express a state of emergency
kaisar from Dutch keizer, raja, maharaja from Sanskrit
surel standard, shortened of surat elektronik (electronic mail), email rarely used in everyday spelling, often used on online spelling (e.g. website-based registration or social account)
mesin also translates as machine in English
padam (of flame or light), punah (of species)
fraksi from English through Dutch suffix fractie
federasi from English through Dutch suffix federatie
keuangan, finansial from English through Dutch suffix financieel
pemadam kebakaran lit. fire extinguisher, branwir from Dutch brandweer (fire defense)

Malaysian: tingkat may be used in Indonesian to express the number of storeys/levels a building has, e.g. a 5-storey building = gedung bertingkat 5
Indonesian: lantai also refers to floor as ground surface in both languages
mebel  from Dutch meubelen  furnitur, perabot rumah tangga
preman from Dutch vrijman (lit. free-man), gangster from English
stik golf, pemukul golf, tongkat golf

Malaysian:
kerajaan 
derived from raja (king) - used in Malaysia and Brunei - in Indonesian means "kingdom"
Indonesian:
pemerintah 
derived from perintah (order/instruction) - used in Indonesia and also in Singapore, despite the fact that Malaysian is the official language

Malaysian: gabenor, Yang di-Pertua Negeri (in Malaysian states)

Indonesian: kelompok, grup from Dutch pronunciation of groep

Malaysian: ibu pejabat "ibu" also means "mother" or "ma'am" in both languages.

Indonesian: kerudung, jilbab though these words have different meaning
jamu often understood as traditional potion made from rhizomes, also means "guest" ("tamu") and "treat the guest" ("menjamu").
rumah sakit influenced by Dutch ziekenhuis (house of the sicks) - This term is still used in Brunei, but in Malaysia, "hospital" has replaced the term completely since the 1960s.
Hungaria, Hongaria substandard, influenced by Dutch Hongarije
saya, aku, gue/gua (slang, informal; from Chinese dialects "ua")

Malaysian: dadah colloquial use in Indonesia means "goodbye"e.
Indonesian:
narkoba an acronym for NARKotika dan OBat-obatan terlArang (narcotics and illegal drugs), 
NAPZA less frequent - an acronym for NArkotika, Psikotropika dan Zat-zat Adiktif (narcotics, psychotropics, and addictive chemical substances)
imigrasi from English through Dutch suffix immigratie
impotensi from English through Dutch suffix impotentie, lemah syahwat colloquial
internasional, antarnegara (sometimes used: mancanegara from Javanese meaning: foreign land)
warnet an acronym for "WARung interNET" (internet shop/cafe)
Italia the original name for the country
izin, lisensi from English through Dutch suffix licentie
Lisboa from Portuguese, Lisabon influenced by Dutch Lissabon
hakim from Arabic حَكِم - used in Malaysian to refer to judges, magistrat less common

Malaysian: lelaki, laki-laki, jantan (for animals, depending on the context, it can mean masculine or used as a derogatory term on men)
Indonesian: laki-laki, pria, lelaki, jantan (on animals, used on men to describe masculinity)
militer from French militaire through Dutch militair
motor, sepeda motor lit. "motorized bicycle" - influenced by Dutch motorfiets

Malaysian: surat khabar coined from two Arabic words: ṣūrat - صورة / صورت (form, appearance) and khabar خبر (news)
Indonesian: koran, surat kabar (more formal - lit. news letter)

Indonesian: angka, nomor - nomer substandard spelling from Dutch/German nummer

jalan pinggir, jalur jalan untuk pejalan kaki, laluan jalan kaki, kaki lima

copet (contraction of colong dompet- wallet thief), pencopet
bajak laut, perompak (perompak in Malaysian, means "robber")

surau, musala, mushollah (from Arabic, 'sh' is usually pronounced as 's')
